questions.question_text: During an upgrade, the wireless infrastructure has seen a few access points join and then drop off the network. After further investigation, it appears the access points may have an IOS code version that is causing issues. Where in the controller is this information found?

discussion.content: Should be B only, because question is asking for some AP join and then drop, show ap image all , shows the number of AP failed to download the IOS.

If you want to see the AP code version, both A and B are correct.
If you want to see the WLC software version, both C and D are correct.
The question is about the AP code, so both A and B are the correct ones.

https://community.cisco.com/t5/wireless-and-mobility/access-point-ios-update-with-a-cisco-5500-wlc/td-p/1700693
Says WIRELESS > Access Points > All APs
What if a person have color blindness or sensitive eyes. Is Cisco testing your knowledge ?

Cisco recommends a minimum RSSI of -67 for voice.
The map shows a very small area that may be appraoching -70dbm, so voice users would have problems in that area. However it is very close to being voice ready so this one is not very obvious.

questions.question_text: Which two services require an RToWLAN design? (Choose two.)

DRAG DROP -
Drag the propagation behavior on the left to the corresponding environment on the right.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
I would switch Diffraction and Reflection.
Reflection - Metal
Diffraction - body of water

Truth is every place where you can define reflection you can define Multipath, you must have some reflection to get multipath. We awlays have up-fade and down-fade Multipath gain/loss isues with point-to-point shots over large bodies of water. Is multipath&reflection. Any room can have both. Cisco questions suck more when you know more sometimes. There is multiple answers for both.

I agree with MWas. 

Diffraction is when over a long distance, the signal spreads around an object and can "heal itself", makes much more sense. Multipath also makes more sense for the Office with cabinets example since the signal will be reflected in many different directions.
Should be: Distant Point to Point with Obstacles -> Diffrection and Metal Cabinets in Dense Office -> Multipath ( others are OK)

For perspective, you might use/see a 69-dB Wi-Fi loss over a distance of about 13 to 28 meters.
Reference: CCNA-Wireless-200-355-Official-Cert-Guide, page 22
Transmit Tx power - 4dB + 2dBi - 69dB +2dBi - 4dB = -45dBm
Transmit Tx power = -45 + 4 -2 + 69 -2 + 4 = 28 bBm

For perspective, you might use/see a 69-dB Wi-Fi loss over a distance of about 13 to 28 meters.
Reference: CCNA-Wireless-200-355-Official-Cert-Guide, page 22
someone know how to resolve this question? I think that the value of free space path loss is missed too.
Fully agree with xtrattitude4u, we missed -69dB for free space path loss.

Since the diagram gives no value for the free space path loss, you can't answer the question as it is shown.

Assuming 28dBm is actually the correct answer, the free space path loss must be -69db:
28dbm - 4dB + 2dBi - 69dB +2dBi - 4dB = -45dBm
